MFV '''''Bugaled Breizh''''' is a Breton [[Commercial trawler|trawler]] from [[Loctudy]], [[Finistère]], whose sinking with all hands in 90 metres of water on 15 January 2004 remains unresolved. While it appeared possible that the ship was pulled under by a [[submarine]], a specific submarine could not be identified from among the number of submarines of several nations operating in the general vicinity of the accident site. Moreover, the condition of the ship's recovered trawling equipment was reported by a technical inquiry to not be consistent with a submarine entanglement.<ref>http://www.bea-mer.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/RET_BUGALED_BREIZH_En_Site.pdf</ref>
==The accident== The motorized fishing vessel (MFV) was built in 1986 by the Bretagne Sud shipyard in [[Belz, Morbihan|Belz]].<ref name=miramar>{{csr|register=MSI|id=8429|shipname=Bugaled Breizh |accessdate=2009-08-09 }}</ref> ''Bugaled Breizh'' (Children of [[Brittany]]) capsized with five sailors about {{convert|14|nmi|km}} southwest of [[Lizard Point, Cornwall]] on 15 January 2004 at 12h25 [[UTC]]. Weather in the area at the time was southwesterly winds of 25-30 knots and 2-3 mile visibility. The ship briefly radioed that it was sinking, and disappeared apparently very quickly; only two bodies of the five sailors were recovered at the time, while a third body was recovered on 10 July 2004 during salvage operations in 90 meters of water depth.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/3884115.stm | work=BBC News | title=Third body recovered from trawler | date=11 July 2004 |accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref>
== Inquiry == Immediately investigations were started by the French authorities in [[Quimper, Finistère|Quimper]]. Several explanations were advanced to explain the capsizing including a fishing accident, collision with a surface ship, rock or wreck, the presence of a sandbank, and an accident involving a submarine.<ref name=dsm/> In June 2004 the ship was raised for forensic examinations. The fish hold showed a compression due to the water pressure. In the absence of evidence of any ramming, the hypothesis of a collision with a surface ship could be abandoned.
===Submarine entanglement theory === Several hours after the sinking an announcement was made by the French [[Maritime Prefect]] for the Atlantic that a [[NATO]] naval exercise involving submarines was taking place in the area. The Dutch submarine {{HNLMS|Dolfijn|1990|2}} was one of the first ships to reach the site of the sinking and was suspected to be involved in the accident.<ref name=dsm>{{cite web| url= http://www.dutchsubmarines.com/news/news_dolfijn4_bugaled_breizh.htm |title=Dolfijn and the Bugaled Breizh | publisher = Dutch Submarines| accessdate= 8 July 2015}}</ref> The British submarine {{HMS|Turbulent|S87|2}} was also suspect as it was sent for repair after the exercises. However, according to authorities ''Dolfijn'' was at least {{convert|15|km|nmi}} away and the [[Royal Navy]] indicated as well that its submarines were not at the site where ''Bugaled Breizh'' sank.<ref name=dsm/> Other reports mention that the {{ship|German submarine|U-22|S171|2|up=yes}}, the British nuclear attack submarine {{HMS|Torbay|S90|2}}, and two French nuclear attack submarines, {{ship|French submarine|Rubis|S601|2}} and {{ship|French submarine|Saphir|S602|2}}, were also present in the vicinity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.corlobe.tk/article648.html#La-carte-des-zones-d-exercice-de |work=Le portail des sous-marins |title=Bugaled Breizh: erreurs et omissions pour "Pièces à conviction" |language=French |publisher=Corlobe |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081104072417/http://www.corlobe.tk/article648.html#La-carte-des-zones-d-exercice-de |archivedate=November 4, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Another submarine noted in the area was {{HMS|Triumph|S93|2}}.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.irishseashipping.com/news/2008/04_2008/04_2008.htm| title=Bugaled Breizh |publisher=Irish Sea Shipping|date=20 April 2008 | accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> Further, there was apparently a submarine of unknown origin that was observing the NATO maneuvers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corlobe.tk/article5592.html |work=Le portail des sous-marins |title=Un sous-marin espion accusé d'avoir coulé le Bugaled Breizh |language=French |publisher=Corlobe |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031024711/http://www.corlobe.tk/article5592.html |archivedate=October 31, 2007 }}</ref>
The hypothesis that ''Bugaled Breizh'' was sunk by an accident with a submarine can explain a number of unusual observations. The ship apparently sank very rapidly, there was no launching of any rescue boat, and the help signal was brief, without giving the coordinates.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/cornwall/3886983.stm |first=Jonathan |last=Morris |title=Answers sought on trawler tragedy |date=12 July 2004 |accessdate = 8 July 2015 | work=BBC News}}</ref> The trawler line of the ship was drawn out on the port side in contrast to the starboard one. The long cable is also reported to have traces of titanium; it has been proposed that this originates from the surface of a submarine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishseashipping.co.uk/archives/subsite/news/2006/09_2006/092006.htm |title=Bugeled Breizh Enquiry |publisher=Irish Sea Shipping |date=2006-09-27 |accessdate=2009-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723110842/http://www.irishseashipping.co.uk/archives/subsite/news/2006/09_2006/092006.htm |archivedate=July 23, 2011 }}</ref>
NATO documents have been declassified and were released to the French judiciary. The Minister of Defense [[Michèle Alliot-Marie]] indicated to the National Assembly<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/12/cri/2004-2005/20050211.asp#TopOfPage | title = Questions for the Government | publisher = Assemblée nationale | language = French |date=4 May 2005 |accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> that the information she had did not allow her to suspect a submarine as the cause of the accident. She indicated that the British and French authorities had cooperated and provided a list of all their ships and submarines in the area of interest. Also, the titanium issue was considered trivial as [[titanium dioxide]] is a common pigment of marine paint including the one used for ''Bugaled Breizh''.
The report of the French Marine Accident Investigation Office ([[Bureau d'enquêtes sur les événements de mer]] or BEAmer) was published on 27 November 2006 and examined a number of possible causes; it rejected the proposition that fishing lines got entangled with a military submarine and concluded that "the hypothesis that the fishing line got buried in a sandbank is more consistent with the evidence."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beamer-france.org/enquetes/enquetes.htm |title=Official report |publisher=BEAmer |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110052744/http://www.beamer-france.org/enquetes/enquetes.htm |archivedate=January 10, 2016 }}</ref> However, the hypothesis of a fishing accident was received with skepticism by the fishing community. It believed that the governmental BEA — it is under the jurisdiction of the [[Minister of Transport (France)|Ministry of Transport]] — tried to avoid a diplomatic incident with the military and its allies.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.letelegramme.com/gratuit/generales/regions/bretagne/bugaled-breizh-la-bataille-des-magistrats-20080731-3542761_1411763.php | language = French | title = Bugaled Breizh : La Bataille des magistrats |date=31 July 2008 | publisher = Le Télégramme |accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> An analysis of the French Institute of Research for the Exploration of the Ocean subsequently rejected the proposition of BEAmer as impossible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france-info.com/spip.php?article57622&theme=9&sous_theme=11 |publisher=France Info |title=Rejection of thesis of fishing accident |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624060434/http://www.france-info.com/spip.php?article57622&theme=9&sous_theme=11 |archivedate=June 24, 2008 }}</ref>
Expert testimony indicated that a nuclear submarine that got entangled in the net of a trawler could pull down a vessel of about 250 tons within 80 seconds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Fatal-trawler-probe-t-trace-culprit/story-11707990-detail/story.html| title=Fatal trawler probe can't trace 'culprit'| date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2015 |publisher=western morning news}}</ref>
A recent newspaper article states that an unnamed witness thought that British submarine ''Turbulent'' may have been involved in the ship's sinking.<ref name="express20101211">{{cite news |url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/justice/bugaled-breizh-un-temoin-evoque-un-sous-marin-britannique_944482.html |title=Bugaled Breizh: un témoin évoque un sous-marin britannique |work=L'Express |language=French |date=11 December 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> However Judge Brigette Lamy said she agreed with reports that the submarine was in Plymouth at the time.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-21230597 | work=BBC News | title=Submarine HMS Turbulent 'in port during Bugaled Breizh trawler sinking' | date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref>
On September 9, 2015, the British ministry of Defense Penny Mordaunt recognized that a British submarine caught the trawl of the Irish fishing trawler "The Karen" on April 15, 2015, in an incident similar to that of the Bugaled Breizh.<ref>http://www.agencebretagnepresse.com/38312</ref>
===Conclusion of inquiry without specific cause=== On 31 July 2008, the judges Richard Foltzer and Muriel Corre, who had been charged with the inquiry into the sinking of ''Bugaled Breizh'', after having received expert testimony, issued a statement that a "highly probable cause" that the vessel sank was as a result of an accident with a nuclear [[attack submarine]].<ref>http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/fatal-trawler-probe-t-trace-culprit/story-11707990-detail/story.html</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4378899.stm | work= BBC News | title = French trawler Bugaled Breizh 'was sunk by sub' | date=24 March 2005 | accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> However, they were unable to indicate which submarine was involved and indicated also the possibility that the accident may have been caused by the unidentified spy submarine or other technically feasible causes.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2002813.ece |first=Adam |last=Sage |title=Spy submarine is blamed for sinking trawler in war games |date=28 June 2007 |accessdate=23 February 2009 | location=London | work=The Times}} {{subscription required}}</ref> As such the relatives of the dead sailors and the owner of the ship have not received any compensations.
While other causes for the ship's loss are possible, this accident and others with a clearer attribution to nuclear submarines suggest that submarines operating in fishing zones represent a danger to fishing trawlers who when "catching" a submarine may be at significant risk of being pulled under. The [[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]] indicates that accidents with submarines may have accounted for the loss of more than 20 motorized fishing vessels since 1970 with the loss of over 150 sailors and demands better communication between the military and the civilian authorities.

A '''Carthaginian peace''' is the imposition of a very brutal "peace" achieved by completely crushing the enemy. The term derives from the peace imposed on [[Ancient Carthage|Carthage]] by [[Ancient Rome|Rome]]. After the [[Second Punic War]], Carthage lost all its colonies, was forced to demilitarize and pay a constant tribute to Rome and could enter war only with Rome's permission. At the end of the [[Third Punic War]], the Romans systematically burned Carthage to the ground and enslaved its population.
==Origin== The term refers to the outcome of a series of wars between Rome and the [[Phoenicia]]n city of Carthage, known as the [[Punic Wars]]. The two empires fought three separate wars against each other, beginning in 264 BC and ending in 146 BC.
At the end of the [[Third Punic War]], the Romans laid siege to [[Carthage]]. When they took the city, they killed most of the inhabitants, sold the rest into [[slavery]], and destroyed the entire city. There is no ancient evidence for modern accounts that the Romans [[salting the earth|sowed the ground with salt]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ridley|first1=R.T.|title=To Be Taken with a Pinch of Salt: The Destruction of Carthage|journal=Classical Philology|volume=81|issue=2|pages=140|year=1986|jstor=269786|doi=10.1086/366973 }}</ref>
By extension, a Carthaginian peace can refer to any brutal peace treaty demanding total subjugation of the defeated side.
==Modern use== Modern use of the term is often extended to any peace settlement in which the peace terms are overly harsh and designed to accentuate and perpetuate the inferiority of the loser. Thus, after [[World War I]], many (the economist [[John Maynard Keynes]] among them<ref>Keynes, John Maynard. ''The Economic Consequences of the Peace''. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Howe, 1920.</ref>) described the [[Treaty of Versailles]] as a "Carthaginian Peace."
The [[Morgenthau Plan]] put forward after [[World War II]] has also been described as a Carthaginian peace, as it advocated the deindustrialization of Germany. It was intended to severely curb the influence of German power in the region and to prevent its remilitarization, as had occurred after World War I ([[Remilitarization of the Rhineland]]). The Morgenthau Plan was dropped in favor of the [[Marshall Plan]] (1948–1952), which entailed the rebuilding of Western European infrastructure, particularly in West Germany.
General [[Lucius D. Clay]], a deputy to general [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] and, in 1945, [[Military Governor of the U.S. Occupation Zone in Germany]], would later remark that "there was no doubt that [[JCS 1067]] contemplated the Carthaginian peace which dominated our operations in Germany during the early months of occupation. This is while the US was following the Morgenthau Plan."<ref>A Nation at War in an Era of Strategic Change, p.129 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=3l7U7Mgmy80C&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=there+was+no+doubt+that+JCS+1067+contemplated+the+Carthaginian+peace+which+dominated+our+operations+in+Germany+during+the+early+months+of+occupation&source=web&ots=0DA1V0w7WA&sig=dSd7upp-P4OlW28bBQKnsKXbBxk&hl=it&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=6&ct=result#PPA129,M1 Google Books])</ref> Clay would later replace Eisenhower as governor and as commander-in-chief in Europe. The Marshall Plan was favored as a revival of the West German economy was considered to be necessary for the recovery of the economy of Europe. West Germany was regarded as a key bulwark against the Eastern Bloc.

A '''cellular microarray''' (or cell microarray) is a [[laboratory]] tool that allows for the [[multiplex (assay)|multiplex]] interrogation of living [[cell (biology)|cells]] on the surface of a solid support. The support, sometimes called a "chip", is spotted with varying materials, such as [[antibodies]], [[proteins]], or [[lipids]], which can interact with the cells, leading to their capture on specific spots. Combinations of different materials can be spotted in a given area, allowing not only cellular capture, when a specific interaction exists, but also the triggering of a cellular response, change in [[phenotype]], or detection of a response from the cell, such as a specific [[secretion|secreted]] factor.
There are a large number of types of cellular microarrays:
# [[Reverse transfection]] cell microarrays. David M. Sabatini's laboratory developed reverse-transfection cell microarrays at the [[Whitehead Institute]], publishing their work in 2001. # [[PMHC Cellular Microarrays]]. This type of microarray were developed by Daniel Chen, Yoav Soen, Dan Kraft, Patrick Brown and Mark Davis at [[Stanford University Medical Center]].

{{Infobox animal | name = | image = Crimean Tom.jpg | caption = The stuffed cat in the collection of the National Army Museum, London, purchased in the 1950s, that may be Tom | othername = Sevastopol Tom, Tom | species = Cat | breed = | gender = Male | birth_name = | birth_date = {{circa}}1847 | birth_place = | death_date = 31 December 1856 | death_place = | resting_place = [[National Army Museum]], London | resting_place_coordinates = {{coord|51.486111|-0.16|display=inline,title}} | known_for = Leading British and French soldiers to food during the Crimean War | owner = Lieutenant William Gair }}
'''Crimean Tom''' (also known as '''Tom''' or '''Sevastopol Tom''') was a cat noted for his association with the British Army during the [[Crimean War]]. Found by Lieutenant William Gair in [[Sevastopol]] after a year-long siege, he is said to have led British forces to valuable caches of hidden supplies that helped ease starvation among the troops. Gair brought Tom back to England after the war but the cat died soon afterwards. He was stuffed and presented to the [[Royal United Services Institute]]. A cat bought in a [[flea market]] in the 1950s resides in the collection of the [[National Army Museum]] and is sometimes described as being Tom, but there is no proof it is the same cat.
== Life == During the [[Crimean War]] British and French forces captured [[Sevastopol]] from the Russians on 9 September 1855 after an [[Siege of Sevastopol (1854–55)|almost year-long siege]]. Lieutenant William Gair of the [[6th Dragoon Guards]], who was seconded to the [[Royal Army Service Corps|Field Train Department]] as a [[Commissariat|deputy assistant commissary]], led patrols to search the cellars of buildings for supplies.<ref name=grey>{{cite book|last1=Wood|first1=Stephen|title=Those Terrible Grey Horses: An Illustrated History of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards|date=2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781472813497|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bm-ICwAAQBAJ|accessdate=14 February 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name=nam>{{cite web|title=Stuffed tabby cat 'Crimean Tom', 1855|url=https://collection.nam.ac.uk/detail.php?acc=1958-02-27-1|website=National Army Museum|accessdate=14 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> Gair noticed a cat, covered in dust and grime, that was sitting on top of a pile of rubbish between two injured people. The cat, unperturbed by the surrounding commotion, allowed himself to be picked up by Gair.<ref name=grey/> The cat, estimated to have been 8 years old when found, had survived within the city throughout the siege.<ref name="grey" /><ref name=nam/>
Gair took the cat back to his quarters and he lived and ate with a group of British officers who initially named him ''Tom'' and later ''Crimean Tom'' or ''Sevastopol Tom''.<ref name=grey/> The occupying armies were struggling to find supplies, especially of food, in a city much-deprived by the year-long siege. It is said that the officers noticed how fat Tom was getting and realised he must have been feeding off a good supply of mice nearby. Knowing that the mice may themselves have been feeding off hidden Russian supplies, they followed Tom to an area cut off by rubble.<ref name=super>{{cite book|last1=Morgan|first1=Ashley|title=Super Cats: True Tales of Extraordinary Felines|date=2017|publisher=Summersdale Publishers Limited|isbn=9781786851277|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jq5IDgAAQBAJ|accessdate=14 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> Here, they found a storeroom with food supplies that helped to save British and French soldiers from starvation.<ref name="grey" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Meet England's most heroic cats|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-36987284|accessdate=14 February 2018|work=BBC News|date=6 August 2016}}</ref> Tom later led the officers to several smaller caches of supplies near the city docks.<ref name=grey/> After the war ended Gair brought Tom back with him to England to keep as a pet but the cat died on 31 December 1856.<ref name=nam/>
== Legacy == [[File:A welcome arrival 1855.jpg|thumb|''A Welcome Arrival, 1855'', John Dalbiac Luard, 1857]] Gair had Tom stuffed and presented to the [[Royal United Services Institution]]. A stuffed cat purchased at the [[Portobello Road]] market by Lady [[Faith Compton Mackenzie]] in the 1950s was identified as Crimean Tom but there is no proof it is the same cat. It was donated to the [[National Army Museum]] in 1958 and is on display there; however, they have not been able to confirm whether or not this is Crimean Tom.<ref name=nam/>
Tom has popularly been identified as the cat asleep on a table next to a wood stove in the oil painting ''A Welcome Arrival, 1855'' by [[John Dalbiac Luard]], an 1857 work depicting British officers opening packages sent from home. It has been suggested that Gair is the red-coated figure at the left of the piece. The National Army Museum write, however, that "there is no evidence to substantiate any of these claims".<ref>{{cite web|title=A Welcome Arrival, 1855 (c), John D'Albiac Luard|url=http://prints.national-army-museum.ac.uk/image/378919/john-dalbiac-luard-a-welcome-arrival-1855-c|website=National Army Museum|accessdate=14 February 2018|language=en}}</ref>

{{ill|Léopold-Émile Reutlinger|fr}}.]] '''Céline Émilie Seurre''', known as '''Cécile Sorel''' or the '''Comtesse de Ségur''', by marriage (7 September 1873 in [[Paris]] – 3 September 1966 in [[Trouville-sur-Mer]]) was a French comic actress. She enjoyed great popularity and was known for her extravagant costumes. ==Biography== She was attracted to the theater at an early age, studying with [[Louis-Arsène Delaunay]] and Marie Favart. In 1899, she began her career at the [[Théâtre de l'Odéon|Odéon]] and then, in 1901, became a member of the [[Comédie-Française]], where she specialized in playing a [[stock character]] known as the "grande coquette". She was especially well known for her portrayal of Célimène in ''[[The Misanthrope]]''. In 1904, she became the 339th "[[Sociétaires of the Comédie-Française|Sociétaire de la Comédie-Française]]" and remained with the theater until 1933. Although long engaged to [[Whitney Warren]], an American architect who was related to the [[Vanderbilts]], she eventually married the Comte de Ségur-Lamoignon, great grandson of the famous [[Countess of Ségur|Comtesse de Ségur]], who acted under the name [[Guillaume de Sax]]. They were sometimes mocked as "beauty and the beast" and were separated after fifteen years, but she kept the title of "Comtesse" for the rest of her life. In 1909, she had the starring role in ''[[La Tosca (1909 film)|La Tosca]]'', a film by [[André Calmettes]] and [[Charles Le Bargy]]. Her next film role did not come until 1937, when she played an aged courtesan in ''[[Pearls of the Crown]]'' by [[Sacha Guitry]]. Four years later, she essentially played herself in a sketch comedy called ''Les Petits riens'', written by and starring [[Yves Mirande]]. In 1944, she barely escaped the bombing that destroyed the Théâtre-Français in [[Rouen]]. In 1950, she underwent a "conversion" and, following the lead of the original Comtesse de Ségur, took her vows as a [[Secular Franciscan Order|Third-order Franciscan]]. She adopted the name "Soeur Cécile de l'Enfant-Jésus" and devoted her time to writing. A television documentary of her career was produced in 1965. She died of complications from a fractured hip, suffered in a fall at her rented château on the French coast, and was buried in the [[Cimetière du Montparnasse]]. Her likeness appears in a [[fresco]] by [[Charles Hoffbauer]] on the ceiling of the [[cupola]] at the [[Château d'Artigny]] in [[Montbazon]], once owned by [[François Coty]]. A college in the town of [[Mériel]] is named after her. == Further reading == * ''Cécile Sorel: An Autobiography'' ("Les Belles Heures de Ma Vie") translated by [[Philip John Stead]], Staples Press, 1953. Roy Publishers, 1954. * ''La confession de Célimène'', Volume 2 of "Souvenirs", Presses de la Cité, 1949 == External links == {{commons category|Cécile Sorel}} * [http://www.ina.fr/video/CAF86014202/hommage-a-celimene-cecile-sorel-video.html "Hommage à Célimène (Cécile Sorel)"], a video narrated by [[Béatrix Dussane]] from the [[Institut national de l'audiovisuel]] (INA). * [http://www.ina.fr/video/I00019162 "Comtesse de Ségur"], a video by Henry Magnan and Yannick Bellon from the INA. * [http://gallica.bnf.fr/Search?ArianeWireIndex=index&p=1&lang=FR&q=cecile+sorel Documents related to Cécile Sorel] @ [[Gallica]]. * {{IMDb name|id=0814791}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sorel, Cecile}} [[Category:1873 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:French stage actresses]] [[Category:French film actresses]] [[Category:French silent film actresses]] [[Category:20th-century French actresses]] [[Category:Comédie-Française]] [[Category:Sociétaires of the Comédie-Française]] [[Category:Burials at Montparnasse Cemetery]] [[Category:People from Paris]] [[Category:Deaths from falls]] [[Category:Secular Franciscans]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Dante'' Sonata}} [[File:Inferno Canto 29, Gustave Dorè.jpg|thumb|The highly [[Program music|programmatic]] themes depict the souls of Hell wailing in anguish.]] '''''Après une lecture du Dante: Fantasia quasi Sonata''''' (French for ''After a Reading of Dante: Fantasia quasi Sonata''; also known as the '''''Dante'' Sonata''') is a [[piano sonata]] in one [[Movement (music)|movement]], completed by Hungarian composer [[Franz Liszt]] in 1849. It was first published in 1856 as part of the second volume of his ''[[Années de pèlerinage]]'' (''Years of Pilgrimage''). This work of [[program music]] was inspired by the reading of [[Dante Alighieri]]'s most famous [[Epic poetry|epic poem]], the ''[[Divine Comedy]]''.
== Background == [[File:Dante Sonata 1.png|thumb|300px|Introduction]] The ''Dante'' Sonata was originally a small piece entitled ''Fragment after Dante'', consisting of two thematically related [[Movement (music)|movements]], which Liszt composed in the late 1830s.<ref name="hamilton">{{cite book|last=Hamilton|first=Kenneth|authorlink=Kenneth Hamilton|title=Liszt: Sonata in B Minor|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Bska8j2Hbm0C|year=1996|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-46963-5|pages=19–20}}</ref> He gave the first public performance in Vienna, during November 1839.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Vienna: Musical History of the Fourth Quarter of 1839 |newspaper=General Musical Newspapers |volume=42 |issue=1 |pages=91–92 |date=January 1840 |postscript=<!--None--> |language=de}}</ref> When he settled in [[Weimar]] in 1849, he revised the work along with others in the volume, and gave it its present title derived from [[Victor Hugo]]'s own work of the same name.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etudes-litteraires.com/hugo.php |title=Les Voix intérieures (1837), XXVII |accessdate=2007-12-28 |author=Hugo, Victor |date=1836-08-06 |work=Études littéraires |language=fr}}</ref> It was published in 1858 as part of ''[[Années de pèlerinage]]''.<ref name="hamilton" />
== Composition == [[File:Dante Sonata 3.png|thumb|300px|The second subject is a derivation of the first]]
The piece is divided into two main subjects. The first, a chromatic theme in [[D minor]], typifies the wailing of souls in Hell. D minor is a common key for music relating to death, as evidenced by Liszt's [[Totentanz (Liszt)|''Totentanz'']]<ref>{{IMSLP|work=Totentanz, S.126 (Liszt, Franz)|cname=''Totentanz''}}</ref> and the statue scene of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Wolfgang Mozart]]'s ''[[Don Giovanni]]''. The first theme also heavily uses the [[Tritone]] (augmented 4th or diminished 5th); this interval was known as the Devil's interval (or "Devil in music") and further reinforces the hellish imagery. The second theme is a [[Beatification|beatific]] chorale in [[F-sharp major]], derived from the first, which represents the joy of those in Heaven.<ref name="walker">{{cite book|last=Walker|first=Alan|authorlink=Alan Walker (musicologist)|title=Franz Liszt: The Virtuoso Years (1811–1847)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lCw4cxHmpgYC|year=1987|publisher=[[Cornell University Press]]|location=New York|isbn=0-8014-9421-4|pages=275–277}}</ref> The key is also symbolic here, being the signature for other uplifting works of Liszt's, including ''Benediction of God in Solitude'' (part of ''[[Harmonies poétiques et religieuses]]'')<ref>{{IMSLP|work=Harmonies poétiques et religieuses III, S.173 (Liszt, Franz)|cname=''Benediction of God in Solitude''}}</ref> and ''Les Jeux d'eaux à la Villa d'Este'' (''Années de pèlerinage'', Vol. 3, No. 4).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.piano.ru/scores/liszt/gs3-04.pdf |title=''Les Jeux d'eaux à la Villa d'Este'' sheet music |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-12-28 |author=Liszt, Franz |work=Piano.ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091210214617/http://www.piano.ru/scores/liszt/gs3-04.pdf |archivedate=December 10, 2009 }}</ref> The secondary theme may also represent [[Beatrice Portinari|Beatrice]], as it is interspersed within chromatic areas, similar to the character's appearances in hell. The piece ends with a rapid chromatic octave section that when played at speed seems to split into three distinct themes, reflecting the three heads of Satan in Dante's [[Inferno (Dante)|''Inferno'']].
== See also == * [[Dante Symphony]] * [[Piano Sonata in B minor (Liszt)]]

{{Infobox person |name = Abdulredha Mohamed Hasan Buhmaid |image = Abdulredha Buhmaid on floor.jpeg |image_size = 200px |caption = Buhmaid bleeding on ground after being shot |birth_name = عبدالرضا محمد حسن بوحميد |birth_date = 28 September 1982<ref name="bici" />{{rp|429}} |birth_place = [[Malkiya, Bahrain|Malkiya]], [[Bahrain]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2011|2|21|1982|9|28|df=yes}}<ref name="bici" />{{rp|429}} |death_place = [[Manama]], Bahrain |death_cause = [[Live ammunition]]<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/03/29/bahrain-investigate-deaths-linked-crackdown "Bahrain: Investigate Deaths Linked to Crackdown"]. [[Human Rights Watch]]. 29 March 2011. Retrieved 3 August 2012.</ref> |resting_place = Malkiya, Bahrain |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = |nationality = [[Bahrain]]i |known_for = being the seventh fatality of the [[Bahraini uprising (2011)]],<ref name="HRW 28.2.2011"/> the first to get killed by army forces. |alma_mater = |employer = |relations = |parents = |party = |footnotes = }}
{{Campaignbox Bahraini uprising}} {{Contains Arabic text}}
'''Abdulredha Mohamed Hasan Buhmaid''' (or ''Buhamaid'', {{lang-ar|عبدالرضا محمد حسن بوحميد}}) was a 28-year-old [[Bahrain]]i protester shot by a live [[bullet]] in the head on 18 February 2011. He died in hospital three days later, the seventh death in the [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Bahraini uprising]].
Buhmaid was among a group of protesters who on 18 February marched toward the [[Pearl Roundabout]] following the funeral procession of protester [[Ali Abdulhadi Mushaima]], who was killed four days earlier. When the protesters neared Pearl Roundabout, the [[Bahrain Defense Force|army]] opened fire. Buhmaid collapsed to the ground, and blood poured from his head after it was [[Ballistic trauma|hit by a bullet]]. The army opened fire twice more. Protesters regrouped after each round of shooting. [[Public Security Forces|Riot police]] finally intervened and dispersed protesters. Over one hundred protesters were injured, some seriously. Buhmaid was taken to [[Salmaniya hospital]] where attempts to revive him failed over the course of three days. He died on the afternoon of 21 February.
Several witnesses including journalists and medics accused authorities of shooting directly at protesters, preventing some ambulances from reaching the site and firing at others. The [[Cabinet of Bahrain|government]] however, denied those statements. It stated that [[warning shot]]s were fired in the air and accused protesters of faking injuries. An investigation by a [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry|government-appointed commission of inquiry]] blamed the army for Buhmaid's death. The incident marked the first time that the [[Royal Bahraini Army]] was used to confront civilians, and at the time was considered "the bloodiest" incident since protests erupted.
Following the incident, the government offered dialogue which the opposition said they will only take part in after the withdrawal of the army. The [[General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain|general labor union]] called for a general strike. Internationally, the attack on protesters was condemned by [[Barack Obama]] and [[Human Rights Watch]]. [[High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy|High Representative]] of European Union expressed her deep concerns and called for restrain and immediate dialogue. Britain revoked over forty arms licenses to Bahrain after an earlier announcement that it would review them and [[President of Germany|German president]] canceled a planned visit to the country. Buhmaid is remembered by the [[Opposition (Bahrain)|opposition]] as a [[martyr]], leader and symbol of [[Nonviolent resistance|peacefulness]].
==Short biography==
Buhmaid (or ''Buhamaid'',<ref name="bici" />{{rp|429}} 28) was married and had three children. He lived in [[Malkiya, Bahrain|Malkiya]],<ref name="Wasat 19.2.2011">{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527966/1.html "الرصاص الحي يخترق رأس شاب وصدر آخر"]. ''Al Wasat''. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref> south west of [[Manama]]. According to his wife, he had strong ties with his brothers.<ref name="Al Wasat 24.2.2011"/> In an interview with the Bahraini newspaper [[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|''Al Wasat'']], she said he used to take part in any political event in his area.<ref name="Al Wasat 24.2.2011"/> "He was hoping to be Malkiya's first martyr and so he became", she added.<ref name="Al Wasat 24.2.2011">{{ar icon}} Zainab al-Tajer (24 February 2011). [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3093/news/read/528653/1.html "زوجة الشهيد عبدالرضا: زوجي ضحَّى بحياته لأجل هذا الوطن"]. ''Al Wasat''. Retrieved 31 July 2011.</ref>
==Background==
{{further|Day of Rage (Bahrain)|Bloody Thursday (2011)}}
[[File:Protesters gathering in Pearl roundabout.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters gather for the first time in Pearl Roundabout on 15 February.]]
Inspired by the successful uprisings in [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]] and [[2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]], [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|protests]] erupted in Bahrain on 14 February.<ref name="AJE 14.2.2011">[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html "Bahrain activists in 'Day of Rage'"]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. 14 February 2011. Retrieved 25 June 2012.</ref> During the day named as the [[Day of Rage (Bahrain)|Day of Rage]], over 6,000 people participated in fifty-five<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|68–9, 70}} demonstrations and political rallies in twenty-five different locations throughout Bahrain.<ref name="Al Wasat 15.2.2011"/> [[Public Security Forces|Security forces]] responded to protests by firing tear gas, rubber bullets, sound bombs and [[birdshot]].<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|68}} More than thirty protesters were injured and [[Death of Ali Abdulhadi Mushaima|Ali Mushaima]] died as a result of birdshot injury in his back.<ref name="bici">{{cite report |title=Report of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry |publisher=[[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]] |url=http://files.bici.org.bh/BICIreportEN.pdf |date=23 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBjs0IJ?url=http://files.bici.org.bh/BICIreportEN.pdf |archivedate=28 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>{{rp|69, 229}}<ref name="Al Wasat 15.2.2011">{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3084/news/read/527311/1.html "قتيل وأكثر من 30 مصاباً في مسيرات احتجاجية أمس"]. ''Al Wasat''. 15 February 2011. Retrieved 25 June 2012.</ref> The following day, during the deceased funeral, another protester was [[Death of Fadhel Al-Matrook|killed]] the same way.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|70, 229–30}} Angry protesters marched to and occupied [[Pearl Roundabout]]. By nightfall, their numbers had swelled to over 10,000.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|71}}<ref name="Raucous Protest">{{registration required|date=April 2011}} {{cite news | author = [[Michael Slackman|Slackman, Michael]] | work = [[The New York Times]] | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html?partner=rss&emc=rss | title= Bahrain Takes the Stage with a Raucous Protest | date=15 February 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref> On 16 February, thousands of protesters continued to occupy Pearl Roundabout.<ref name="alj_16Feb">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Bahrain Protesters Hold Ground – Anti-Government Protests Continue in Tiny Kingdom, Despite Apology by King for the Deaths of Two Demonstrators |date=16 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera English |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wY7a5QCD?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html |archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
On 17 February (later referred to as the [[Bloody Thursday (2011)|Bloody Thursday]]), police launched a [[pre-dawn raid]] on sleeping protesters.<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)">{{cite news | author=Martin Chulov | title = Bahrain protests: Four killed as riot police storm Pearl Square | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-protests-riot-police-storm-pearl-square?INTCMP=SRCH | accessdate=18 January 2012}}</ref> Four protesters were killed and more than 300 were injured bringing the number of those killed in the events to six.<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)"/><ref name="bbc231injured">{{cite news | author = Staff | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286 | title = Bahrain Protests: Police Break Up Pearl Square Crowd | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref> Health workers and a [[Miguel Marquez|journalist]] were allegedly attacked by security forces.<ref name="HRW report">{{cite report |title=Targets of Retribution: Attacks against Medics, Injured Protesters, and Health Facilities |pages=14–15 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |date=18 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="ABC 16.2.2011">{{cite news | author=Ned Potter | title = Bahrain Protests: At Least 2 Dead in Crackdown; ABC's Miguel Marquez Roughed Up | date=16 February 2011 | publisher=[[ABC News]] | url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/bahrain-protests-abc-news-correspondent-miguel-marquez-beaten/story?id=12936124 | accessdate=12 January 2012}}</ref> The [[Bahrain Defence Force|army]] was deployed following clearance of Pearl roundabout which then set up checkpoints and barriers.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011">{{cite news | author=CNN Wire Staff | title = After crackdown, army makes show of force in Bahrain's capital | date=18 February 2011 | publisher=[[CNN]] | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/17/bahrain.protests/ | accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Clashes Rock Bahraini Capital – Armoured Vehicles Seen on the Streets of Manama after Police Storm Protest Site in Roundabout, Killing at Least Six |date=17 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera English |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wZPVZfFG?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |archivedate=17 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|The Interior Ministry]] issued a warning to stay off the streets,<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb"/> and the army warned that it was ready to take "punitive measures" to restore order.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|75}} Protesters resorted to [[Salmaniya Hospital]]'s car parks where thousands of them protested against the government.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|75}}<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)"/><ref name="DWB report">{{cite report |title=Health Services Paralyzed: Bahrain’s Military Crackdown on Patients |publisher=[[Doctors Without Borders]] (Médecins Sans Frontières) |page=2 |url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/publications/reports/2011/Bahrain_BP_Final_06042011_2106_FR-EN%20LOGO.pdf |date=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(3)">{{cite news | author=Martin Chulov | title = Bahrain's quiet anger turns to rage | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=''The Guardian'' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrains-quiet-anger-turns-rage?INTCMP=SRCH | accessdate=23 January 2012}}</ref> All 18 Members of Parliament from [[Al Wefaq]], the only opposition political party represented in Parliament, submitted their resignations.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|75}}
==Incident==
[[File:Bahrain army open fire on protesters.ogv|thumb|Video of the shooting went "viral", with more than two million views in the space of a week.<ref>{{cite news| last=O'Neill|first=Megan|title=This Week In Viral Videos – Slam Dunks, Angry Birds & World News|work=SocialTimes|date=25 February 2011|accessdate=1 August 2012|url=http://socialtimes.com/this-week-in-viral-videos-slam-dunks-angry-birds-world-news_b39796}}</ref>]]
{{ external media | align = right | video1 = {{YouTube|afBh3GJ6PNo|Montage of clips of shooting filmed from behind BDF lines}} | image1 = [http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2011/02/19/article-1358570-0D4252AE000005DC-375_642x436.jpg Protesters carrying Buhmaid overhands]. | image2 = [http://www.bahrainrights.org/BCHR/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Buhmeid1.jpg Buhmaid undergoing a surgery in Salmaniya hospital]. }} [[File:Bahraini protesters praying in front of Army.JPG|thumb|Protesters performing [[Maghrib prayer]] in front of the army.]]
On 18 February, over 50,000<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011"/> participated in the funerals of crackdown victims.<ref>Frederik Richter (18 February 2011). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/18/us-bahrain-cleric-idUSTRE71H1PP20110218 "Bahrain police attack a "massacre": Shi'ite cleric"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> One was held in [[Al Daih]],<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> another in [[Karzakan]].<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/> The largest however, was in [[Sitra]].<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011"/> At about 4:46 in the afternoon, about a thousand protesters, most of them young men who participated in Al Daih funeral of [[Death of Ali Abdulhadi Mushaima|Ali Abdulhadi Mushaima]] marched toward Manama,<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011">[[Michael Slackman]] and Nadim Audi (18 February 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/19/world/middleeast/19bahrain.html?src=mv "Security Forces in Bahrain Open Fire on Protesters"]. ''New York Times''. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> defying the government [[Curfew|ban on gatherings]].<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2011/02/18/133861291/bahrain-mourners-call-for-toppling-of-monarchy "More Blood In Bahrain As Troops Fire On Protesters"]. [[NPR]]. 18 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> By 5:18 they had reached a road junction; to the right was Salmaniya hospital and to the left Pearl Roundabout.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> They turned left after a short pause.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> On their way, they clashed with riot police who withdrew from the site. Protesters continued their march removing barriers set by police a day ago.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78, 233}}
By 5:30<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011"/><ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/> protesters were 80 to 200 meters away from army forces stationed in Pearl Roundabout which "were armed with [[M16 rifle|M16 assault rifles]], Dilmun rifles and [[M2 Browning|Browning .50 calibre machine guns]] mounted on top of armoured vehicles".<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78, 233}} The protest was peaceful and protesters were "holding their hands in the air and chanting 'peaceful, peaceful'".<ref name="HRW 28.2.2011"/><ref name="NYT blog"/> Some were holding flowers.<ref name="FT 19.2.2011">{{registration required}} Simeon Kerr, Robin Wigglesworth and Michael Peel (19 February 2011). [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/64b55622-3b32-11e0-9970-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2274A2uFy "Troops fire on Bahraini protesters"]. ''[[Financial Times]]''. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> As protesters continued marching, army troops opened fire.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78, 233}}<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/><ref name="HRW 18.2.2011">{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Bahrain: Army, Police Fire on Protesters|work=|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=18 February 2011|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/18/bahrain-army-police-fire-protesters|format=|doi=|accessdate=25 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBg3kZL?url=http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/18/bahrain-army-police-fire-protesters|archivedate=28 July 2012|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
Abdulredha Buhmaid was among the protesters. He was shot by a [[bullet]] in the head, collapsed to the ground and in the words of a witness, "blood was rushing from his head".<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78, 233–4}} Others sustained severe injuries inflicted by gunshots, two of whom also fell to the ground.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78, 233–4}} Several eyewitnesses said army troops "gave no warning",<ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/><ref name="BBC 18.2.2011"/> but one witness said he heard them issue a warning several minutes after the initial shooting.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|234}} Another witness said they heard a "faint voice of someone over a loudspeaker in the distance but could not make out what the speaker was saying".<ref name="HRW 28.2.2011">{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Bahrain: Hold Perpetrators of Crackdown Accountable|work=|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=28 February 2011|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/02/28/bahrain-hold-perpetrators-crackdown-accountable|format=|doi=|accessdate=27 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBC1e42?url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2011/02/28/bahrain-hold-perpetrators-crackdown-accountable|archivedate=28 July 2012|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
Most protesters ran after hearing gunshots and a helicopter chased them.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> After shooting stopped, protesters regrouped.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> One youth picked a rock and headed toward the army, only to be stopped by four other protesters.<ref name="FT 19.2.2011"/> A witness interviewed by [[Physicians for Human Rights]] said that he and other protesters moved closer to army forces following the initial shooting.<ref name="PHR"/> According to him he asked "Why do you shoot us? We had our hands up. We are peaceful. What do you want from us?", one soldier replied "I want you to leave. If you do not turn back, I have orders to shoot".<ref name="PHR">{{Cite report |author=[[Physicians for Human Rights]] |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=April 2011 |title=Do No Harm: a Call for Bahrain to End Systematic attacks on Doctors and Patients |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/PHR_Reports/bahrain-do-no-harm-2011.pdf |publisher=[[Amazon S3]] |page=14 |docket= |accessdate=31 July 2012 |quote=Physicians for Human Rights spoke with one Shi’a youth who witnessed the killing of Abdul-Redha Mohammed Buhmaid, a friend and fellow protester shot in the head on 21 February 2011. He felt paralyzed with fear when he saw Abdul-Redha on the ground bleeding profusely from the head, brain matter on the ground next to him. (Abdul-Redha was most probably killed by a high-velocity weapon due to the massive damage to the skull.) Raising their arms, he and several other protesters then walked toward the security forces and said, “Why do you shoot us? We had our hands up. We are peaceful. What do you want from us?” To which one Bahraini military officer replied, “I want you to leave. If you do not turn back, I have orders to shoot.”}}</ref> Arriving ambulances started evacuating the injured when army opened fire again.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/>
When the shooting stopped, about fifty protesters<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704900004576151632161951462?mod=googlenews_wsj "Death Toll Mounts in Gulf"]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> started [[Evening Prayer (Islam)|praying]] on the road,<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> and few stood in front facing the army with their hands in the air.<ref name="TI 19.2.2011">[[Robert Fisk]] (19 February 2011). [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/robert-fisk-in-bahrain-they-didnt-run-away-they-faced-the-bullets-headon-2219267.html "Robert Fisk in Bahrain: 'They didn't run away. They faced the bullets head-on'"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref> The army opened fire for a third time.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78}}<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/><ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/><ref name="TDT 18.2.2011"/> The period of each shooting was short, because "people immediately started running away", witnesses said.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)">[http://articles.cnn.com/2011-02-18/world/bahrain.protests_1_security-forces-barrage-of-tear-gas-canisters-protesters?_s=PM:WORLD "At least 4 dead in Bahrain as violence continues"]. CNN. 18 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref><ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/> After that, riot police intervened, firing tear gas and birdshot to disperse protesters, inflicting more injuries among them.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|78}}<ref name="WP 18.2.2011"/>
A cameraman working for the [[Associated Press]] said he saw "army units shooting [[Anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft weapons]], fitted on top of armored personnel carriers, above the protesters in apparent [[warning shot]]s and attempts to drive them back from security cordons".<ref name="AP 18.2.2011">[http://www.france24.com/en/bahrain-army-troops-fire-protestors-pearl-square-manama-demonstration-violence-wefaq-shia-shiite "Troops open fire on Bahraini protesters"]. [[Associated Press]] (via [[France 24]]). 18 February 2011. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref><ref>Hadeel al-Shalchi (18 February 2011). [http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/18/bahrain-security-forces-fire-tear-gas-on-protest/ "Bahrain security forces fire tear gas on protest"]. Associated Press (via ''[[U-T San Diego]]''). Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> Bahraini [[photojournalist]] Mazen Mahdi said that the army shot "live fire from [[machine guns]]" and that paramedics were blocked from helping the wounded.<ref name="WP 18.2.2011"/> "The first was a warning shot in the air. But after that, they just opened fire at the people ... They shot at the ambulances when they came in", he added.<ref name="WP 18.2.2011">[[Janine Zacharia]] (18 February 2011). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/17/AR2011021702190.html "New clashes erupt in Bahrain after marchers rally in support of king"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref>
A senior emergencies researcher and medics interviewed by [[Human Rights Watch]] confirmed that some of the twelve ambulances sent were prevented by security forces from reaching the site.<ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said ambulances and paramedics "were shot at"<ref name="TDT 18.2.2011"/> and that "several were detained and at least one ambulance was impounded".<ref name="TDT 18.2.2011"/> [[Michael Slackman]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that he and a colleague were "shot at from a helicopter"<ref name="NYT blog"/> shortly after army opened fire on protesters.<ref name="NYT blog">{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Mackey |pages= |title=Feb. 18: Updates on Middle East Protests |date=18 February 2011 |publisher=''The New York Times'' |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/18/latest-updates-on-middle-east-protests-5/ |accessdate=25 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBen2rB?url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/18/latest-updates-on-middle-east-protests-5/ |archivedate=28 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Associated Press witnesses,<ref name="AP 18.2.2011"/> ''The Daily Telegraph'',<ref name="TDT 18.2.2011"/> and ''The New York Times''<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> mentioned that army personnel positioned in high buildings and helicopters fired on protesters. Jalal Firooz, resigned MP of [[Al Wefaq]], Bahrain's main opposition party, said he saw soldiers fire on protesters.<ref name="DW 18.2.2011">[http://www.dw.de/dw/article/0,,6443251,00.html "Troops open fire on Bahrain protesters"]. [[Deutsche Welle]]. 18 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> A [[Human Price of Freedom and Justice|report]] by three local rights groups mentioned that "photos of the injuries suggest that army aimed at the upper body area".<ref>{{Cite report |author=[[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]], [[Bahrain Human Rights Society]] and [[Bahrain Youth Society for Human Rights]] |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=22 November 2011 |title=Bahrain: the Human Price for Freedom and Social Justice |url=http://www.bahrainrights.org/BCHR/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/BahrainTheHumanPrice.pdf |publisher=Bahrain Centre for Human Rights |page=33 |docket= |accessdate=30 July 2012 |quote= }}</ref>
Riot police chased down protesters who fled to Salmaniya,<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011"/> Bahrain's main hospital.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41659383/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/t/bahrain-opposition-rejects-talks-until-army-stops-shooting/ "Bahrain opposition rejects talks until army stops shooting"]. [[msnbc]]. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> Security forces backed off after initially advancing toward the hospital<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011"/> and firing tear gas into it.<ref name="CBC">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/02/18/bahrain-monarchy-protests.html "Bahrain police fire on protesters"]. [[CBC.ca]]. 18 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> That night, over seven thousand protesters staged an anti-government sit-in in hospital parks, described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as "the only place in Manama where they now feel safe to gather in numbers".<ref name="Guardian 18.2.2011">Martin Chulov (18 February 2011). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-protests-regime-fall "Bahrain protest: 'The regime must fall, and we will make sure it does'"]. ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> The incident marked the first time that the [[Royal Bahraini Army]] was used to confront civilians,<ref name="TDT 18.2.2011">Adrian Blomfield (18 February 2011). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/bahrain/8334771/Bahrain-royal-family-orders-army-to-turn-on-the-people.html "Bahrain royal family orders army to turn on the people"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref> and at the time was considered "the bloodiest" incident since protests erupted.<ref name="TIME 18.2.2011">Aryn Baker (18 February 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2052645,00.html "Carnage in Bahrain as the Military Opens Fire"]. ''[[TIME]]''. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref>
===Casualties===
{{further|Casualties of the Bahraini uprising (2011–present)}}
[[File:A protester shot in his leg.jpg|thumb|Protester injured in his leg being carried in a civilian car]]
At least 120 people were injured according to medical officials.<ref name="BBC 18.2.2011">{{cite news |first= |last= |pages= |title=Bahrain troops 'fire on crowds' |date=18 February 2011 |publisher=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12509658 |accessdate=25 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBhFcG6?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12509658 |archivedate=2012-07-28 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Salmaniya hospital was "overwhelmed"<ref name="WP 18.2.2011"/> with casualties, some of whom were taken to private hospitals.<ref name="WP 18.2.2011"/> Doctors said that nine of the thirty-two casualties who reached Salmaniya hospital were in critical condition.<ref name="TDT 18.2.2011"/> Some medics cried while treating the injured, some of whom had bullets still lodged into their bodies, X-rays showed.<ref name="AP 18.2.2011"/><ref name="AJE 18.2.2011">[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112184122210251.html "Bahrain forces fire at protesters"]. Al Jazeera English. 18 February 2011. Retrieved 30 July 2012.</ref> A doctor interviewed by [[Al Jazeera English]] pleaded for help from "all countries in the world".<ref>{{cite video |people=Dr Ghassan |year=2011 |title=Bahraini doctor pleads for help |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dJtapAw5HbQ |format= |medium=YouTube |trans_title= |publisher=Al Jazeera English |location=Bahrain |accessdate= |time= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> Describing the situation in hospital as a war, Dr. Ghassan said, "They are shooting at people's heads. Not at the legs. People are having their brains blown out".<ref name="AJE 18.2.2011"/> Two doctors said they treated patients who "seemed to be [injured by] live bullets rather than shotgun pellets, judging by the entry and exit holes".<ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/>
Buhmaid was taken to Salmaniya hospital. Blood was still "pouring from his head and he was unconscious".<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|234}} He was "clinging to life"<ref name="AJE Doc"/> in intensive care unit where doctors "struggled to stop his bleeding".<ref name="AJE Doc"/> "This is a bullet, gunshot wound, direct to his head and he's bleeding profusely from his nose, from his ear, his brain is shattered into pieces", said a doctor. Buhmaid's "brain was destroyed, but his body was still alive".<ref name="AJE Doc">{{cite video |people=May Ying Welsh and Tuki Laumea |year=2011 |title=Bahrain: Shouting in the Dark |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/2011/08/201184144547798162.html |format= |medium= |trans_title= |publisher=Al Jazeera English |location=Bahrain |accessdate=29 July 2012 |time=8:30 |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote=In intensive care, a man named Abdulredha was clinging to life. Doctors struggled to stop his bleeding. 'This is a bullet, gunshot wound, direct to his head and he's bleeding profusely from his nose, from his ear, his brain is shattered into pieces. I don't know the name of the patient, I don't care about the name of the patient; they are all patients here.' Redha's brain was destroyed, but his body was still alive. The team rushed him to surgery. |ref= }}</ref> His clinical death prompted a nurse on 20 February to smash a glass-framed image of the [[Prime Minister of Bahrain|Prime Minister]].<ref>[http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//RTV/2011/02/22/RTV506911/?s=Bahrain+Salmaniya+February&st=0&pn=1 "BAHRAIN: Killing of protester triggers new demonstrations in Bahrain"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6DXxSnXp4?url=http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//ITVProgs/1992/01/07/Y05870109/ |date=2013-01-09 }}. [[ITN Source]]. Reuters. 22 February 2011. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref> Remaining in ICU for three days,<ref>{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3091/news/read/528339/1.html "رصاصة الجيش تنهي حياة عبدالرضا"]. ''Al Wasat''. 22 February 2011. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref> Buhmaid was medically declared to be dead early in the afternoon of 21 February,<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|233}} becoming the seventh victim of the uprising.<ref>{{ar icon}} Amani al-Maskati (21 February 2011). [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3090/news/read/528284/1.html "السلمانية تعلن عن وفاة عبدالرضا محمد حسن بوحميد"]. [[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|''Al Wasat'']]. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref>
Listing him under "Deaths Attributed to Security Forces",<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|228}} the [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]] appointed by [[King Hamad]] to investigate the events stated that Buhmaid's death "may be attributed to the BDF [army]"<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|234}} while also referring to the contrary result of the military investigation.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|234}}
===Government account===
On the night of 18 February, Fasial al-Hamar, then the Minister of Health, issued a press release aired on the [[Bahrain Radio and Television Corporation|national TV]] which denied there had been any deaths. He said the situation at Salmaniya hospital was calm and that only seven people were being treated for minor injuries.<ref name="Wasat 19.2.2011"/> He also warned against what he called "rumors" spread in some satellite channels and websites.<ref name="Wasat 19.2.2011"/> Bahrain's ambassador to the United States said that if army forces did fire live ammunition, "Probably they were warning shots only".<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/> "The forces that were used were proportional according to the law, they were legal, they were necessary because they were stopping the shops. The economy was hurting, the national economy. We had to take action and action was taken by the law," he added.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/> However he admitted protesters did not use live rounds and promised that "Investigations will happen. And they will continue".<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/>
The army said that protesters defied its orders to evacuate the area.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|77–8, 234}} According to its statement, after at least fifteen minutes of repeating the same orders, soldiers fired warning shots to the air.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|77–8, 234}} It also alleged that protesters were accompanied by "a line of ambulances" out of which they took blood bags to "feign that they had been injured".<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|77–8, 234}} Military prosecutors carried out an investigation and concluded that the trajectory of the bullet that killed Buhmaid were inconsistent with the bullet having been shot by the BDF, on the basis of an ordnance expert's report that concluded the shot was fired from a high elevation.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|234}}
==Aftermath==
Following the incident, the government offered dialogue with opposition and ordered army to withdraw from Pearl Roundabout.<ref name="France 24(2)">[http://www.france24.com/en/20110219-bahrain-orders-tanks-off-streets-protests-manama-pearl-square "Bahrain military withdraws from capital Manama"]. Associated Press (via France 24). 19 February 2011. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref> On 19 February, army troops were replaced by riot police.<ref name="France 24(3)"/> Hundreds of protesters moved to the site from different locations.<ref name="France 24(3)"/> A standoff between protesters and riot police was created, until the latter suddenly moved away.<ref name="France 24(3)"/> Thousands of protesters re-occupied the site following police withdrawal.<ref name="France 24(3)">[http://www.france24.com/en/20110219-bahrain-protesters-return-pearl-square-after-army-withdrawal-khalifa-prince "Protesters return to Pearl Square as army withdraws"]. Reuters (via France 24). 20 February 2011. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref>
===Funeral===
Buhmaid's funeral was held on 22 February in his village, [[Malkiya, Bahrain|Malkiya]].<ref name="Al Wasat (2)"/> Over 9,000 participated in the funeral procession which started from roundabout 13 in [[Hamad Town]] and ended in Malkiya graveyard.<ref name="bici"/>{{rp|88}}<ref name="Al Wasat (2)">{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3091/news/read/528441/1.html "حشود تشيع الشهيد عبدالرضا بوحميد إلى مثواه الأخير بمقبرة المالكية صباح اليوم"]. ''Al Wasat''. 22 February 2011. Retrieved 26 July 2012.</ref> At the same day during afternoon, over 100,000<ref name="Independent 22.2.2011">[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/bahrain-king-orders-release-of-political-prisoners-2222371.html "Bahrain king orders release of political prisoners"]. ''The Independent''. Associated Press. 22 February 2011. Retrieved 7 July 2012.</ref><ref name="NYT 22.2.2012">{{cite news|last1=Slackman|first1=Michael|last2=Manama|first2=Nadim Audi|first3=Michael|last3=Slackman|first4=J. David|last4=Goodman|title=Protests In Bahrain Become Test of Wills|work=The New York Times|page=8|date=23 February 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/23/world/middleeast/23bahrain.html}}</ref> participated in a protest dubbed "[[March of loyalty to martyrs]]" in honor of the seven victims of the uprising.<ref name="BBC 22.2.2011">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12535681 "Bahrain unrest: Thousands join anti-government protest"]. BBC News. 22 February 2011. Retrieved 7 July 2012.</ref>
===Medics' trial===
{{main|Bahrain health worker trials}}
In May 2011, 47 doctors, nurses, and dentists were charged for their actions during the uprising.<ref name="Al Wasat (3)"/> One of the charges was conducting unnecessary operations to Buhmaid, which led to his death.<ref name="Al Wasat (3)"/> In a press conference, [[Judiciary of Bahrain|Minister of Justice]] said "Buhmaid was shot in the head and he underwent a surgery in the presence of the media. His head had been open in an exaggerated manner, which led to his death".<ref name="Al Wasat (3)">{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3161/news/read/559278/1.html "47 طبيباً وممرضاً من «السلمانية» يواجهون 13 تهمة"]. ''Al Wasat''. 4 May 2011. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref>
==Reactions==
===Domestic===
Buhmaid's family said they were sad for his death, but their pride had overcome it.<ref name="Al Wasat 24.2.2011"/> Appearing on the national TV, the [[Salman bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa|crown prince]] authorized by his [[King Hamad|father]], the [[King of Bahrain|king]], offered unconditional dialogue with opposition.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> He offered "condolences to the people of Bahrain for the painful days they are living" and asked them to remain calm.<ref name="NYT 18.2.2011"/> Opposition activists demanded withdrawal of army and resignation of government for the dialogue to begin.<ref name="AJE 19.2.2011">[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011219443971206.html "Bahraini protesters fired upon"]. Al Jazeera English. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 2 August 2012.</ref> "[There is no] serious will for dialogue because the military is in the streets", said [[Matar Matar]], resigned MP of Al Wefaq.<ref name="AJE 19.2.2011"/> The [[General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain|general labor union]] called for an indefinite general strike "unless the army is pulled out from the streets and peaceful demonstrations are permitted".<ref>[http://www.france24.com/en/20110219-bahrain-labour-union-calls-general-strike-demand-right-peaceful-protest "Labour union calls for indefinite general strike"]. AFP. France 24. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 2 August 2012.</ref>
===International===
{{further|International reactions to the Bahraini uprising (2011–present)}}
[[Barack Obama]] criticized the government actions. In reference to government of Bahrain and Yemen, he said "The United States condemns the use of violence by governments against peaceful protesters in those countries and wherever else it may occur".<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(2)"/> [[Catherine Ashton]], the [[High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy|High Representative]] of European Union demanded "restraint" from all parties and said that report of violence "deeply concerned" her.<ref name="AJE 19.2.2011"/> She called for dialogue to begin "without delay".<ref name="AJE 19.2.2011"/> The United Kingdom revoked forty four arm licenses to Bahrain, twenty of them open licenses.<ref name="TDT (2)"/> Foreign Office Minister [[Alistair Burt]] said "We are deeply concerned about the situation in Bahrain and the events which have led to the deaths of several protesters".<ref name="TDT (2)">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/bahrain/8335188/Britain-revokes-arms-licences-to-Bahrain-and-Libya.html "Britain revokes arms licences to Bahrain and Libya"]. ''The Daily Telegraph''. 19 February 2011. Retrieved 25 July 2012.</ref>
German president canceled a planned trip to the country.<ref name="DW 18.2.2011"/> "Freedom of assembly and freedom of speech in Bahrain have to be fully guaranteed", a spokesman quoted him saying.<ref name="DW 18.2.2011"/> [[Lawrence Cannon]], then Canada's [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Foreign Minister]] called the Bahraini government to "exercise restraint" and lunch an investigation into protesters' deaths.<ref name="CBC"/> "Canada urges Bahrain to respect its citizens' rights to freedom of expression and assembly, and to engage in peaceful dialogue with its people to address their concerns", he added.<ref name="CBC"/>
[[File:A memorial for Abdulredha Buhmaid-cropped.jpg|thumb|Memorial for Buhmaid]]
Human Rights Watch condemned the attack. "The Bahraini army has done what the Egyptian army did not do and exactly what the United States and its other partners urged it not to do -- it has opened fire on its own people," its Washington director said.<ref name="HRW 18.2.2011"/> [[Fareed Zakaria]], [[CNN]]'s international affairs analyst, said that the crackdown on protesters was a "rash move that will enrage many of its people and cost the regime international prestige".<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(3)"/> "This is a terrible mistake and they will pay a heavy price for it. The regime in Bahrain is doing something very rash and unwise; it is trying to respond by using force and punitive measures. This is not going to work in the end", he added.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(3)">{{cite news | author=[[Fareed Zakaria]] | title = Bahrain will pay heavy price for crackdown | date=18 February 2011 | publisher=CNN | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/02/18/zakaria.bahrain.mideast/index.html?iref=allsearch | accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref>
==Legacy==
Buhmaid was the first person named a "[[Field marshal|field commander]]" by [[February 14 Youth Coalition]],<ref name="BHM 27.1.2012">{{ar icon}} [http://www.bahrainmirror.com/article.php?id=2886&cid=74&st=%DA%C8%CF%C7%E1%D1%D6%C7%20%C8%E6%CD%E3%ED%CF "أذهبُ عميقاً في دمكم أذهب بعيداً: سيرة قائد ميداني"]. ''[[Bahrain Mirror]]''. 27 January 2012. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref> which also named their attempt to reoccupy Pearl Roundabout in the first anniversary of the uprising, "operation of the martyr leader Abdulredha Buhmaid".<ref name="BHM 14.2.2012"/> His death was described by the online opposition newspaper, ''[[Bahrain Mirror]]'', as a "legendary scene that will remain forever in the conscience of humanity".<ref name="BHM 27.1.2012"/> A poster found in two articles of the aforementioned newspaper described Buhmaid as "the martyr who brought down an army with his peacefulness".<ref name="BHM 14.2.2012">{{ar icon}} [http://www.bahrainmirror.com/article.php?id=3131&cid=73&st=%DA%C8%CF%C7%E1%D1%D6%C7%20%C8%E6%CD%E3%ED%CF "عملية الشهيد عبدالرضا بوحميد: نجاح يلامس مركز الثورة.. كسر هيبة العسكر واضطرار الحكم لإنزال المدعات"]. ''Bahrain Mirror''. 14 February 2012. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref><ref>{{ar icon}} Nasser Zain (24 November 2011). [http://www.bahrainmirror.com/article.php?id=2385&cid=115&st=%DA%C8%CF%C7%E1%D1%D6%C7%20%C8%E6%CD%E3%ED%CF "بسيوني: وقَبّلتْ الرصاصة رَأسَ "بوحميد""]. ''Bahrain Mirror''. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref>
Speaking to participants of a sit-in front of United Nations building in Manama on 22 February 2012, Ahlam al-Khuza'e of Al Wefaq said that shooting scene of Buhmaid was "the top manifestation of peacefulness".<ref>{{ar icon}} [http://www.manamavoice.com/index.php?plugin=news&act=news_read&id=8654 "البحرينيون يعتصمون أمام الأمم المتحدة ويستنكرون التجاهل الدولي لقضيتهم"]. ''Manama Voice''. 22 February 2012. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref><ref>{{ar icon}} [http://www.bahrainmirror.com/article.php?id=3235&cid=73&st=%DA%C8%CF%C7%E1%D1%D6%C7%20%C8%E6%CD%E3%ED%CF "اعتصام حاشد أمام مقر الأمم المتحدة في المنامة تنديداً بالتجاهل الدولي للثورة البحرينية"]. ''Bahrain Mirror''. 23 February 2012. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref> On 29 February, opposition parties organized a gathering in Malkiya to honor Buhmaid.<ref>Andrew Hammond and Hasan Jamali (1 March 2012). [http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2012/Mar-01/165202-bahrain-delays-un-investigator-limits-rights-group-visits.ashx#axzz22CovmawX "Bahrain delays UN investigator, limits rights group visits]. ''[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]''. Reuters. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref> Thousands participated in the gathering including [[Isa Qassim]], Bahrain Shias' top religious figure.<ref>[https://archive.is/20130123104215/http://www.firstpost.com/topic/place/bahrain-bahrains-top-shiite-muslim-cleric-issa-qassem-c-image-02qw63j6GX5gL-6999-1.html "Bahrain image"]. First Post. Retrieved 31 July 2012.</ref>
